review_title: Great and supportive place to work
job_title: Assistant Support Worker in London, England
pros: Really fulfilling, varied and interesting work. Great opportunities for advancement, a lot of training available and very supportive managers and colleagues. The benefits (holiday, mental health support) are also really good.
cons: This type of work can be a bit overwhelming sometimes - can't really be avoided though and I did have great managers and colleagues who supported me throughout.

review_title: Very demanding but can learn a lot
job_title: Floating Support Worker in London, England
pros:
- great place to pick up experience and there is opportunity for training.
- colleagues are driven and are always happy to help.
cons:
- workload can be very demanding with a very high casload.
- not much part time/flexi time opportunities available.
- Pay doesn't reflect the work load in some teams.

pros: Good opportunities, good team, interesting work
cons: Under-resourced and shift work can be stressful

job_title: Assistant Support Worker in London, England
pros: I enjoyed working with the clients. Team was diverse which was nice (age wise, career background wise and cultural background)
cons:
Low pay and huge workload. Assistant Support Workers have the same caseload and case complexity as Support Workers in the team but get paid approx £2,000 less a year which makes no sense. Little to no training was provided. My induction was reading printed out powerpoints with little context and I shadowed some colleagues on visits for 2 weeks before I was assigned my own cases and made to go it alone, despite being completely new to support work. 
It's emotionally draining work and difficult to take leave because of being so overworked. Some of my colleagues would work on their days off and weekends to try to catch up. The targets set were unreachable and unmanageable workload meant that service provided to clients was subpar as there wasn't enough time to work with them properly. There isn't much satisfaction as you didn't have the capacity to make meaningful change in your clients' lives as you were spread so thin. I had a caseload of over 40 people, despite only being there 3 months. I felt like I was doing them all disservice and it was very frustrating. 

The management was chaotic and provided little to no support for staff. We were often understaffed due to high staff turnover or people on long term leave for mental health reasons. I was assigned 3 high risk cases which I was wasn't trained or qualified to manage, because all senior lead workers were signed off sick. It was an incredibly stressful environment and I ended up resigning due to having a nervous breakdown. When I was on sick leave, management called me daily to see when I would be coming back. It was too much.
There was also a strange cliquey work culture which seemed to be based around faith and Christianity, which often led to uncomfortable conversations and questioning of others in the office.

job_title: Social Services Lead Worker in London, England
pros: Some of the most exceptional people staff wise, who want to make a real difference to the lives of others.
cons: Some of the worst people staff wise, who appear to go under the radar (management wise) and get away with atrocious behaviour.

pros: Thames Reach is a charity
cons: It works in the charitable sector

pros: Thames reach gave me opportunity for training and development , they teach me everything I know today and because of that training I have full time job in homeless sector .
cons: Interview process is really poor . It's like you open the book and reed everything from it . No flexibility on the interview . Even my former manager told me that interview does not reflect on what kind of worker you are . If this is true then please do something about . I was working with people who did really well on interview and then they were constantly off sick :(

pros: Passionate about their aims which is about identifying and supporting people at risk of homelessness, supporting vulnerable adults manage their health and offending issues and engaging them in skills development to participate in the community. The organisation is proud of what they are able to achieve and are inventive within the constraints placed by dwindling social care budgets.
cons: IT systems are managed by contractors as well as payroll. Where the IT company has performed well the payroll team will be best brought back in house to address the service gaps that present itself in a faster manner. The impact of its public service is limited by cuts in social services budgets.

pros: Helping disavantaged clients recover and rehousing. And provide them with different sources of supporting and assistance during his/her progress of turmoil.
cons: I have to dealing  with unsatisfied characters they  don't care about what they think and don't take any suggestions or advice it's no longer team work. Some workers are there only for the money, than for the cause, also there is a jealousy way of challenges dealing with circumstances, where some people trying to show to their managers that are better than anothers, in another words "shapers" always see themselves as the best person to handling the situation. Also they are very gossiping.

review_title: the amazing work they do to help help improve lives. Their morals and values are unrivalled. It’s a special place.

cons: Understandably, very stressful and demanding situations/people due to the nature of the work. Some people evolve with the support give, others not..

review_title: Excellent culture, great team and not everyday is the same
job_title: Human Resources & Recruitment Officer in London, England
pros:
- Diverse! They include everyone no matter who you are. I feel comfortable here unlike some previous companies I worked for.
- Not corporate and strict. Laidback but efficient culture
- The people that work there are great.
- Fulfilled work for a good cause
- Good progression
- Can work from home (flexible working) but depends
cons:
- The workload is intense is not for everyone. Requires a great deal of organisation and strategy.
- Salary, not the best but that's average across the charity sector.

job_title: Housing Options/Support Worker in Hackney, England
pros: Flexible working within the comany, feeling of understanding throughout, great staff in all sectors.
cons: Securing employment with a new company that offers the same perks, privelages, and comradery with work colleagues.
